metadata.category: Building a Haptic Feedback App with CoreHaptics
metadata.title: Introduction to CoreHaptics & Taptic Engine

sections.title: Introduction to CoreHaptics & Taptic Engine
sections.chapter: Chapter 1: Introduction to CoreHaptics & Taptic Engine

inlineContent.text: Understand the core concepts of the CoreHaptics framework and
how the iPhone’s Taptic Engine works.
Taptic Engine is a linear actuator developed by Apple
that generates precise vibration feedback.
Linear vibration
: Unlike traditional motors, provides delicate feedback through linear motion
Fast response
: Precise timing control in milliseconds
Various intensities
: From subtle taps to strong impacts
Check if the device supports CoreHaptics.
Since haptics don’t work in the simulator,
you need to test on a real device.
Let’s look at the main components of CoreHaptics.
CoreHaptics provides two basic event types.
Transient
: Momentary tap feeling (button clicks, collisions)
Continuous
: Sustained vibration (engine sounds, dragging)
Each type is controlled by intensity and sharpness.
Transient events provide short, sharp feedback.
They’re suitable for button taps or toggle switches.
Continuous events are vibrations that last for a certain duration.
They’re used for slider drags or loading states.
You can create various sensations by combining Intensity and Sharpness.
UIKit’s UIFeedbackGenerator is simple but limited.
Use CoreHaptics when you need more fine-grained control.
Feature
UIFeedbackGenerator
CoreHaptics
Difficulty
Easy
Medium
Customization
Limited
Full control
Audio sync
Not possible
Possible
AHAP files
Not supported
Supported
UIFeedbackGenerator only provides predefined feedback.
It’s useful when you want to implement quickly.
When to choose CoreHaptics:
What is the main difference between Transient and Continuous events
in CoreHaptics?
Both events produce vibration.
Audio is handled separately with the AudioCustom type.
Transient only produces sound, Continuous only produces vibration.
Transient is a momentary tap, Continuous is sustained vibration.
Transient is suitable for short feedback like button clicks,
while Continuous is suitable for sustained feedback like slider drags.
Only Transient supports the intensity parameter.
Both events support the intensity and sharpness parameters.
Why is the Taptic Engine superior to traditional vibration motors?
Linear motion enables precise and fast response.
The Taptic Engine is a linear actuator that enables
precise control in milliseconds.
It can produce louder sounds.
The Taptic Engine is a device for tactile feedback, not sound.
It uses more battery to produce stronger vibration.
The Taptic Engine is designed efficiently
to provide precise feedback with less power.
